SEG.ORIGINAL_TEXT: While I disagree with flying Confederate flags, I'm still confused as to why it has become acceptable, even commendable, to take one down without permission.
What happened to freedom of speech?

People in this country, both right and left, only trumpet freedom of speech when they agree with what is being said. Both sides are pretty keen on censorship for the sake of political correctness and "decency".

I think they need to be removed from government buildings. But if some redneck wants to have one on the back of their truck, I guess they can do what they please. What I find amusing is that businesses are learning it pays to be on the right side of civil rights and the right wingers get all butthurt when some company they previously supported suddenly says they are removing a confederate flag or that they're in favor of gay marriage.
Only strengthens the resolve of supporters of the flag.
If someone is taking them down from private property without permission, that is of course not commendable at all.
But a flag flying on public property at the behest of a government isn't about free speech.

Why isn't it commendable ? If you get caught taking down a flag on private property you'll be subject to arrest. Many people have broken the law to make a point. Personally I don't believe in hate crime laws, but it do believe that the less acceptable expressions of hate become, the less likely they are to occur. The Confederate flag is a hateful, inflammatory symbol. People should be ashamed to display it. States banning it from public grounds, corporations refusing to associate themselves with it and individuals breaking the law to express their revulsion are all part of the process of waking people up to what is and isn't acceptable.
Removing flags flown on public lands is a political statement but stealing people's private property is still wrong.
Only the cowards will bend to the will of the majority.The true men of quality stock will fight the terroristic mob with guns and steel if needed be.
Yeah, that worked out REAL well last time.

<img width="267" height="200" alt="The South Will Rise Again by NecroLynLyn" src="http://t01.deviantart.net/hk9zpc-KSu6As-ZiuCXYeQVKvw8=/300x200/filters:fixed_height(100,100):origin()/pre08/4f1c/th/pre/f/2009/034/b/c/the_south_will_rise_again_by_necrolynlyn.jpg" data-src="http://t01.deviantart.net/hk9zpc-KSu6As-ZiuCXYeQVKvw8=/300x200/filters:fixed_height(100,100):origin()/pre08/4f1c/th/pre/f/2009/034/b/c/the_south_will_rise_again_by_necrolynlyn.jpg">
that's a thing I don't understand in the U.S.: You can hurt people's feelings, you can lie and blame people, yell curses and the latter - and always say "hey, freedom of speech b*tch!"
I'd like to compare that to german basic laws:
Every person shall have the right to free development of his personality insofar as he does not violate the rights of others or offend against the constitutional order or the moral law.
which goes right with the first and fundamental law in Germany:
Human dignity shall be inviolable. To respect and protect it shall be the duty of all state authority.

so, in other words: If you have a flag and you harm nobody with it, you're free to raise it, carry it around and do with it whatever you wish. But if there're people you might offend by doing so (like, let's say, you use a symbol for slavery or something that would go against minorities), you mustn't do as you'd hurt these people's dignity - and therefore harm THEIR personal freedom. That however is the limitation of your freedom - the freedom of another one.
Some say this was once called "respect"
The first person choosing to throw a word at someone instead of a stone founded the modern and civilized humanity.
asking for weapons to solve an issue that harmed and hurt so many before is the most immature and unwise thing you can think of.
Because it was wrong of South Carolina to NOT lower their confederate flag down to at least half mast in the wake of the Charleston shooting.
America has never been a country that believed in freedom <i>from<i> offense.
I do agree that they should be taken off government buildings, but that's more the individual states' decision and not the federal government's.

Just wanted to say that not all of us so-called 'right-wingers' are unreasonable assholes. <img src="http://e.deviantart.net/emoticons/w/winkrazz.gif" width="15" height="15" alt=";P" data-embed-type="emoticon" data-embed-id="454" title="Wink/Razz">
I don't think all right wingers are unreasonable assholes.

Mostly I am worried about people who aren't even willing to examine their motives or their reasons or the history behind their beliefs or actions. I have no problem examining mine. In fact, I reconsider my position on things constantly, based on new information.

As I said, I in no way agree with flying a Confederate flag. It IS an inflammatory symbol (though I doubt everyone who flies one does it to make others angry); however, breaking the law to prove a point does not help the situation. It only makes the people who fly the flag angry.
If you want to change something, go about it the lawful way. Unless, of course, there are no other lawful options.
Yeah, I agree. Some people are too stuck in their ways.
Of course, you NEED a base of unchanging core ideals to build your opinions off of.
